text:
Another 'train' question. Sorry! I see some folks are recommending buy in advance and some say buy the day of or the day before.

For those saying "buy in advance" can you give your reasoning?

For those saying "आणखीbuy the day of" your trip or 'day before" can you also give your reasoning?

Everything I read says the fast train tickets are more expensive the closer you get to the day of your trip or they sell out. No one wants to risk that, but we certainly don't want to risk buying tickets and then losing the money altogether if our plans change. This has become a very stressful decision to make! Any suggestions or ideas are greatly appreciated! Thanks!

comments.comment_text: We found buying more than 24 hrs ahead of time was cheaper. It depends on your schedule what will work for you

It depends if you are sure on your plans and whether you are using an express or regional train. I always advise against buying tickets in advance straight after a flight, because if your plane is late and you miss the train you will have to buy a new ticket.
If its a regional train just buy on the day as no discount for buying in advance and you cannot reserve seats for regional trains as mostly used for short trips/
commuters going to work.

I bought our fast train tickets months in advance at early booking specials for about $40 for 2. Day of—tickets were as high as $100 for 2. (Rome to Florence and La Spezia to Rome trips)
(We landed at Rome airport at 7:00am and I booked train tickets from Rome Termini to Florence at 10:35am to give enough time to land, take Leonardo Express…and it worked great—-too much time actually, but better safe than sorry).

If you take High Speed trains or Intercity , Better to make ticket before ( better offers, low prices) . The more you wait, the more you spend...
If you travel with regional (all the rest...) You can make ticket even One minute before departing. No reservation, same price.
If you’re with a group of people, booking last minute may result in not sitting together.
I noticed on the Trentailia website they have a refund option you can add to your ticket cost. Does anyone know anything about this?

We bought day of as I was travelling with 3 kids that aren’t always timely! Only one time we couldn’t get seats together but were able to get tickets to where we were going without a problem during high season in July. While might’ve been more expensive it worked for us without worrying about missing a train. We weren’t going very far each time -Rome-Orvieto then Orvieto-Florenc
e and Florence to Milan. The regional trains it didn’t matter as those seemed to only have 2nd class -those were crowded.
You already said it… price and availability. Only you can decide what level of risk you are willing to take. you can also buy tickets that allow for free or cheap changes.

We bought ours months in advance based on an itinerary that we set up for ourselves giving enough time to get to train stations. Make sure we weren’t going to be late etc. etc. this way we were guaranteed a spot we were able to all sit together and no hassles day of just get on the train when you’re supposed to and that’s it

Buy in advance because I don’t want to deal with my luggage, being vigilant, crowds and buying train tickets. Italian train stations can be extremely busy especially the big ones (Rome, Venice, Milan, Turin). I buy all of my fast trains or “must” cities (the next city that I will have an overnight stay) early in my travel planning. My city stays do not change. Day trips I will buy day of because sometimes it does change (weather, tired, I day trip elsewhere).
I should have booked further out and did not. The tickets cost more the day before. I would have saved at least $40 for the two of us.

Sometimes I buy in advance because I will be already in Italia and must take a certain train within particular timeline to move from one city to another. I usually take advantage of reduced fare for business or executive class for longer distance.

When flying into Italia, I buy tickets when I arrive at the train station. You’ll never know if your flight will be delayed for any reason, how long it will take to go through the Passport Control and the Customs. No stress, no biting nails or pulling your hairs out😉.

Group of 14 travelling together, we will be taking around 20 train rides for this trip. High speed trains I booked in advance to get best prices and to be able to sit together. The rest, we will buy closer to travel date when we’re already in Italy. Our destinations are set, but I built in some flexibility ( advantage of DIY planning).
It is cheaper to book in advance. If you want seating close to each other and well it is one less thing to worry about 😁

I think it's mostly just a matter of how "planned" people like to be. I get anxious if I wing it, especially because this trip had 6 people, so I bought my tickets in advance. Plus, it would've cost a lot more for those six tickets. If it was just my husband and myself, my anxiety would have been less and I might have just purchased the day of.
Buying in advance =cheaper and guaranteed seats together

It is definitely more expensive buying day before or day of but sometimes can be worth it for the flexibility. However, it has happened to me twice that on main routes (Rome to Florence and Florence to Venice) that the train time I wanted/needed to get to my destination was sold out and I had to wait 3-4 hours for the next available train. If neither of these factors are a concern, then no need to book ahead.
Why not a Eurail pass for Italy? That appears to be cheapest imo

We didn’t do any day trips by train but if we had I probably wouldn’t have book in advance. In a day trip you don’t have luggage to worry about.
get a train app. We used Omio with great success. Pickl a train in a month's time and note the price. Check back every week and see if the price changes. They you have the info you need.

I'm all for riding the ferries. I think they offer much better views and sea and sun to boot. I'm not a fan of driving on the Amalfi Coast, and I cannot comment on the traffic in October--only in summer--but here are my views: Should I drive on the Amalfi Coast?
Everyone has their own opinion about renting cars in the Amalfi Coast area. I have done it twice. The traffic moves at a snail’s pace. You often get stuck, unable to pass, behind a truck or bus, breathing diesel fumes. The roads are narrow—often only 1-1/2 lanes wide. There are many curves. When tour buses come around those curves, they frequently cut the corners and don’t really care about other drivers in the other lane. The winding roads resulted in my passengers getting motion sickness. Parking is very, very difficult to find anywhere near a village. You may think you are going to have great views from the road, but often the bushes are too high and obstruct your view. The few vantage points there are are generally so packed with cars that you can’t stop. Last, but not least, because of the horrendous traffic, the local government is going to restrict rental car use. It is my understanding that it will be something like Mexico City, where you can drive on limited days according to your license plate. If you are adventurous and decide to rent a car anyway, be sure it is a small one with full insurance coverage to cover dings and dents. Also, valet parking through your hotel is a must. I personally love riding the ferries from one village to the next. It is my very favorite thing to do there. They give you sea and sun and a unique view of the coastline.
